data.text: Why Not Use a Bicycle Kickstand?
Okay, might be a stupid question but do a lot of experienced cyclists not us kickstands?

My bikes would like you to know that they are upset by the thought of kickstands. (but it depends on the bike/rider. I have road, gravel and cross bikes where it would just be extra weight and potentially risky).
data.author: Simon Tomkins

data.text: please explain the "..potentially risky)." part. And, realistically, how much weight does a kickstand add? I suspect it's relatively negligible.
data.author: Mike Parton

data.text: If a kickstand catches or slips down it's dangerous (especially if the rider doesn't notice). If you're riding any kind of technical terrain, it's another part that doesn't need to be there to risk getting bumped/snagged. My road bike weighs less than 8kg, so even 100g or so is dead weight. Also it would just be wrong.
data.author: Simon Tomkins

data.text: A standard kickstand will not hold up a bike with panniers. As said above they add weight and a small risk to road bikes. I just lean it if I can, lay it on the none gear side otherwise.
data.author: Bill Debs

data.text: This one has 2 :
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: I use a double-leg kickstand, sort of like what motorcyclists use. It will hold my bike up firmly even with fully loaded panniers. Even better, it does double-duty as a work stand, lifting either wheel off the ground if I ever have to repair a tire.
data.author: Tom Montalbano

data.text: ive broken them all lol
data.author: George Homer
Mary Ervin Pinizzotto

data.text: Most simply don't want the extra weight or the potential of it getting in the way...I have one on 1 of my 3 bikes.
data.author: Mark Stratmann

data.text: I asked about this very thing today as I asked for recommendations. It was an honest question but no one replied. I'm glad you asked!
data.author: Jeri Elam

data.text: I'd say if your biking 40 plus km at a time and want to get faster then no kickstand or, at least kickstand optional
data.author: Shane Daly

data.text: extra weight, won’t hold up a heavy bike and plenty of trees, road signs and bike parking furniture out there!
data.author: Biggles Mak

data.text: I regard a kickstand as unnecessary weight and have never missed having one.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: pay expedential amounts to go light and strong then weigh it down with excessories that are just that excess
data.author: John Findlay

data.text: I understand your first point but not the second. I don't have a kickstand. They don't come with road bikes and there's an image problem, rather like putting L plates on a sports car...but I often stop with nothing to lean the bike against where a kick stand would be really useful...think I'll try one, as I'm well past my posing sell by date.
data.author: Tom Jones

data.text: , I have a stand and pass many dressed up men without them. At my destination or any stops in between, stand down and walk away from bike. Stand doesn’t seem to stop me passing them. My daughter’s bike doesn’t have a stand and it annoys me!
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: I just lay my bike down (on the non-drive side). As with many things, its a personal preference.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: ...and when someone falls over it? Or a car driver doesn't see it? Or there just isn't space for a laid down bike? Or your in very muddy lane? Laying a bike down is something I just don't do.
data.author: Tom Jones

data.text: I’ve never had an issue. I have seen kickstands that sink into soft surfaces and the bike topples. As I said before, personal preference.
data.author: Jacquie Gaudet

data.text: I don't bother anymore. I had one on my old touring rig but almost never used it. It was a pletscher and the bike still didn't want to stand up straight when loaded.
data.author: Jake Klamerus

data.text: I do, but unless it’s a pronged center stand, or if you’re pulling a trailer, a regular kickstand is useless when a bike is loaded. There is also a custom bar that props up the bike b the top tube. I’m considering that one hard because my bike won’t take a center stand.
data.author: Diane Farley

data.text: Maybe I am not experienced enough to know what a kickstand is... Or to miss having one.
data.author: Andre Velloso
Rob Eff

data.text: I was being sarcastic...
data.author: Andre Velloso

data.text: I figured as much but you never know!
data.author: Rob Eff

data.text: Most kickstands won’t really hold up a fully loaded bike, but some will. I have a surly troll and some guy has a 3D printed part that you can order online that will create a strong connection for a good kickstand, and I’ve had no problem at all with it, even fully loaded.
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: rubbish
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: so you’re saying I’m lying.
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: rubbish kickstand don't, good ones do.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: re-read my comment. I stated outright that it works with a GOOD kickstand. You saying rubbish to my comment relating my direct experience is equivalent to saying I’m lying.
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: the only picture I have of it. Kickstand is on the other side, of course. It’s not fully loaded, but it does work when it’s weighed down with a full kit.
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text:
this is the part. Contrary to your uninformed comment, it works great, even with a fully loaded touring bike. https://youtu.be/96a9lezOejQ
My kickstand solution for the Surly Troll, Ogre and ECR! Get yours!
youtube.com
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: so Paul, what’s your experience that qualifies you to call me a liar?
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: relax mate. I was saying rubbish kickstands will not hold up a loaded bikes.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: you said rubbish to my comment relating my direct experience, which is equivalent to saying I’m lying. You didn’t say rubbish kickstands don’t work, you just said rubbish to my entire comment, which included the qualifiers that most kickstands don’t work,and that it works only with good kickstands.
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: lol, sorry my response wasn't succinct enough for you.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: jeez, you don’t seem to know the meaning of the word succinct - one word is too succinct, if that’s what you actually meant to say (which I’m sure it wasn’t). You were dismissing my entire point.
data.author: Tony De Jesus

data.text: As others have said, serves no useful purpose, and adds weight and mechanical issue risks, save some money and skip it.
data.author: Lee Orphan

data.text: Serious road cyclists never ever. You should feel free to do what you want though.
data.author: Rich Langston

data.text: that’s a bunch of bs
data.author: Dale Nimmo

data.text: no, that’s a fact. Show me a modern road bike with drop bars and a kick stand. In my whole life I’ve known one guy who used one. I’m pretty old. But as I say, do what you want. But as others here mention, kick stands and panniers are also a poor match.
data.author: Rich Langston

data.text: Idk. My kickstand does pretty well on my 70lb ebike, even with fully loaded panniers. Not a road bike, but still relevant to the weight question.
data.author: Timothy Simpson

data.text: cool. I’m not personally against them, just answering the question asked.
data.author: Rich Langston

data.text: in the same way that road bike do not have bells. Pretty useful but "does not fit with the road bike" or any other excuse not to have one.
data.author: Alain Seront

data.text: serious road cyclist are boring...
data.author: Alain Seront

data.text: you could also lean it on that fence behind for the same effect.
data.author: Christopher Ørr

data.text: Yeah, but why would I do that when a kickstand works just as well without scratching the paint or requiring something to lean on?
data.author: Timothy Simpson

data.text: why would I get a kickstand when I can lean it against something ? In either scenario a fall may/may not scratch the paint, though perhaps slightly less likely with a kickstand.
data.author: Christopher Ørr

data.text: I meant scratches from being leaned up against something, not from a fall (though that could be a concern too. I personally like being able to just hit the kickstand just about anywhere without having to think about finding a good spot to lean it against. I stop to pet dogs and help people with repairs on the trail often enough to where I like the freedom it gives me.
data.author: Timothy Simpson

data.text: i am a blackbelt in finding a lean where the saddle/handlebars are the points of contact.
data.author: Christopher Ørr

data.text: it’s pretty true. Roadies are all about aero. If they are going to spend $$$$ for carbon xyz, they are most likely not going to “add extra weight” with a kickstand. I’ve yet to meet any roadie with a kickstand. Not mtbers either, except for me. I don’t like to lay my bike down. I prefer a kickstand.
data.author: Nalie Lee-Wen

data.text: Last time I checked , this group was about TOURING, not riding at breakneck speed on a lighter than air carbon No matter Allah delights in infinite diversity ( movie line) Do as you choose but just stay out of my way!! Hahaha
data.author: Dale Nimmo

data.text: , I pass many of them. Me and my bike with a stand on it. I don’t look cool though!
data.author: Aaron Davis

data.text: Completely false. Unless you have some personal definition of “serious.”
data.author: Richard Mitchell

data.text: I’m so tired of “serious road cyclists”
data.author: Andy Bennett

data.text: unless the bike frame was designed for a kickstand, there lies the inherent frame damage incurred with the installation and usage. Meanwhile a hair band or rubber band on the front brake lever allows you to lean the bike anywhere and it'll stay put.
data.author: Lawrence Grella

data.text: I don't think touring cyclists and serious road cyclists are the same.
data.author: Sandi Donnenwirth Remson

data.text: Not to themselves.
data.author: Peter Mead

data.text: Awfully handy on a loaded touring bike, but not if your idea of bike is one like they use for racing. I have one it's not a race type but in town if I'm not riding it its locked up to something solid.
data.author: Robert Clark

data.text: No
data.author: Matt von Asten

data.text: My bike has a kickstand; only use it when the bike is unloaded. Quite practical. The extra weight is negligible. Not one of those who cut the toothbrush in half to save on weight.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: You would save more weight by cutting the kickstand in half! 🤔😂
data.author: Graham Ogle

data.text: I agree
data.author: Daniel Sasseville

data.text: All my bikes have a kick stand, and two of them also have a steering lock. If you tour a kick stand comes in handy along with a steer lock to keep the front wheel from turning and tipping over your rig. Weight is NOT a factor as I am not a "Tour de France" nut who's goal is go 30 mph up hills..and shaves all is hair off to save a few oz's....as for "mechanical issues's / risks" I see none....I have done thousands and thousands of miles with a kick stand...NO issues. But like most things its a riders choice....I like my kick stand & Steer lock combination especially when touring.
data.author: Martin Fano

data.text: Back wheel against a solid surface works better than a kickstand. If your bike is loaded a kickstand won’t help anyway. Lay it down or back it into something.
data.author: Eric Eklund

data.text: A lot do and a lot don't
data.author: Steve Shea

data.text:
No. I have a Clickstand just for touring, though. There isn't always something to lean my bike against, and I don't like dumping it on the ground with all the extra weight attached. http://www.click-stand.com/
Click-Stand Home Page
click-stand.com
data.author: Carter AL

data.text: I don't use them, but just saw this cool idea in a video where the world bicycle tourist ("Chains & Chords" YouTube channel "Our Top 5 Bike Touring Gadgets") used a telescoping hiking stick to support the bike underneath the seat. (at about 2 minutes into the video.) I can't really describe it as well as the video.
data.author: Mike Kroeger

data.text: I love the comments about weight. It is a kickstand. Give me a break, these same people will talk about how they have to have their French presses with them. Lol It is about appearance and the fact that many won't hold up your bike unless you get a higher quality one that has a larger footprint. I love mine
data.author: Matt Holtzlander

data.text: You make the point but miss it. Kickstands aren’t about weight (or not that much) but utility. Most of the kickstands around don’t have the large footprint you suggest. Since the bike tends to need to be picked up after it falls over, and since it falls over often, the kickstand becomes more of a hinderance than useful. Useless items don’t need to be carried around. After a while, most riders just get used to leaning the bike up against whatever is handy and the kickstand becomes more useless.
data.author: Stuart Black

data.text: Nope.. they always fail. Find something to lean it on or lay it down..
data.author: Dayne Martins

data.text: I have one, it holds up well under the weight I've had so far (for weekend camping touring), I find turning my wheel in the opposite direction helps stability (I plan on getting a steering lock soon). I wouldn't be without it. When we arrive at a cafe or stop to take pictures, I just pop the kickstand while my husband has to find somewhere to lean that is stable enough. If you want one, get one.
data.author: Victoria James

data.text: If you have one that is designed for carrying your load, you’ll use it! Guaranteed. Although, I just read some of the comments and now I not so sure! Oh well, I have two bikes, one with, one without. I like a stand of some kind. Just my 2 cents!
data.author: Donald Ewen

data.text: I prefer having a kickstand on my city bike but not on my touring rig, which is quite heavy for a kickstand to support. Interestingly enough, Surly, a leading USA manufacturer (in Taiwan) of touring bikes, even goes so far as to void the warranty on frames that have had kickstands installed. While touring, I usually find a pole, wall, or other such object against which to lean the bike.
data.author: Chris Morfas

data.text: Frames need to be made for kickstands, as the torque at the small surface the kickstand is attached to can get quite high, especially when loaded. Quite frankly, I don't understand why top-dollar Surly can't manage to design that in.
data.author: Thomas Arson

data.text: Anyone who says it adds weight is just some ultralight freak, while I'm all for lowering weight, a kickstand definitely helps and I would recommend a double kickstand
data.author: Charles Kempf

data.text: A kickstand isn't even a 1/4 of a pound I don't know what these ultralight freaks are concerned about
data.author: Charles Kempf

data.text: It seems like ultralight riders should be bullemic or have anorexia
data.author: Charles Kempf

data.text: It's actually become somewhat popular in bikepacking but it's a very purpose built kickstand to support the weight of the gear and locks when retracted so there's no mishaps. I always seem to find a tree but if you like a kickstand then you should go with what you like.
data.author: Caleb O'Connor

data.text: Haven't had a kickstand on a bike of mine in about 70 years. I currently own 7 bikes and been through dozens others in those decades.
data.author: Bill Dove
David O'Neill
David O'Neill
David O'Neill
David O'Neill

data.text: Who needs a kickstand……
data.author: David O'Neill

data.text:
I love mine. Lightweight and works perfectly. Click-stand.com
Click-Stand Home Page
click-stand.com
data.author: Matt Campbell

data.text: I have one and it’s my favorite feature
data.author: Mike Wood

data.text: I like to have a cheap kickstand to hold up the bike when you cant find a pole or tree. The trick is to lash a large eye bolt to the original kickstand to reduce the angle the bike leans. This helps with preventing the implosion of the kickstand. In sandy conditions i use a large bottle cap underneath to prevent it from becoming buried too far in and tipping the bike. Since I tour the desert areas primarily a kickstand is a must.
data.author: Lee Colbert

data.text: I think my first question is did the bike come with kick stand new? If yes, do you use it? If yes do you like it. Some bikes have them fitted and are designed to be loaded and have them on the stand.
data.author: Chris Hayworth

data.text: My bike NEVER lays on the ground unless there is serious problems I use a DIY bike support stand that collapses down and weighs almost nothing and yet is a VERY sturdy support I lean my EQ only when necessary or if it’s muddy
data.author: Dale Nimmo

data.text: On a touring bike I do. On a Road bike it'd 50/50 the purist will say it adds weight. On a Mountain Bike you absolutely don't because of the obvious safety concern.
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: Just like the bell. A serious road biker will rather die from running over a pedestrian than adding the extra half ounce for a bell.
data.author: Thomas Arson

data.text: absolutely
data.author: Brian Halley

data.text: I use a click stand. Look them up. They are awesome and made by a small shop out west. I have one for my road bike and one for my tour bike. Love them.
data.author: George Hoffman

data.text: I have one also. Works great!
data.author: Sherry McCune

data.text: I agree. It is so light
data.author: Theresa Finking

data.text: Me too, though I also lean against walls esp when the bags are on. Laying the bike down reduces access to handlebar bag; which is what is used most at stops.
data.author: Alan Edgar

data.text: I always have a kickstand now on all my bikes. Very little extra weight and gives you freedom to not have to lay your bike down or find a wall or pole to lean against.
data.author: Jenny Currie

data.text: I use one. I love it, very practical. Though I don't carry heavy loads when traveling by bike (I just take short trips of less than a week).
data.author: Brooke Anderson

data.text: No kickstands.
data.author: Daniel Barrantes

data.text: Adds weight, so no
data.author: Tom Etheridge

data.text: I think a kickstand is great on a a bike carrying panniers and gear makes standing your bike up a lot easier with weight on it.
data.author: Sonia Anderson

data.text: I ride a Marin Four Corners. Never had a kickstand for years. There are frequent downpours here so it's not always smart to lay my bike on the ground, especially with panniers. I eventually caved and got a kickstand recently and never looked back: why didn't I do this sooner? Started with a single-stem model on one side and it's true that's not very stable on a loaded bike. Switched to a twin-legged kickstand and it's great! I regularly have >15kg on the rear rack and the stand works great! It also takes the rear wheel off the ground so I can do some light maintenance on the rear wheel if I have to like oiling my chain or cleaning the cassette after my ride. I'm a kickstand convert.
data.author: Martin Lim

data.text:
Steerstopper baby! https://steerstopper.com
SteerStopper®
steerstopper.com
data.author: Kurt Franke

data.text: A kickstand is simply a delay mechanism, so your bike falls down after you've walked away. 🙂 [note: not true of double leg kickstands used by some touring cyclists]
data.author: Mike Kruger

data.text: I do multi day touring and i love my kickstand. It's so convenient when you stop. I didn't have one for ages and bought one when touring in Europe. It meant i could keep the bike very close to me when having lunch...and i kept my panniers on. Very convenient. The weight is very little for the convenience. No scratches to frame either.
data.author: Nevi Gorup

data.text: Yeah, I actually like having my bike near me when I'm stopped somewhere for a break.
data.author: Martin Lim

data.text: Love my kickstand.
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: Right now!
data.author: Paul Hamon

data.text: never used one, Lean it against everything or lay it down
data.author: Richard Reitman

data.text: You don’t need a kickstand. Bike racks, trees, get creative. There’s so many other ways to prop your bike up then mounting a kickstand to your bike. Lay it down gently it’ll be ok.
data.author: John Harington

data.text: I think it really depends on what kind of riding you are doing and the type of bike.
data.author: Andree Sanders

data.text: What do you mean by "experienced" though? I've ridden in this city for a decade and my bikes always have a kickstand (I did use something similar to the ClickStand for my last recumbent, which isn't exactly a kickstand). I don't always use it though, sometimes it's not needed. It's possible to stand a bike using a pedal against a curb, sometimes it leans against a rack, but I'm not going to give up the ability to free-stand it. And I don't worry about weight because I trust my gearing to go fast, and I go pretty quickly (and my bike isn't "light" and my gearing is internal which means more weight).
data.author: Jared Lauridsen

data.text: Most of my bikes have one, even on my crosshybrid and one of the mtb’s. It’s nice to be able to park properly whilst in town. Only have one without but that’s my sporting routine mtb. Happy trails
data.author: Maurits Veenhuis

data.text: I don't need/have/use one. I'm not fussed about weight but don't like bringing things I don't use (besides bicycle & human first aid).
data.author: Richard Neville

data.text: I had a kickstand on my touring bike, heavy duty one which would withstand 40kg. Never went over 40kg of bike and gear, but it started to buckle, so I took it off and never looked back.
data.author: Stipe Stajp Predanic

data.text: If you stop for a break in the middle of nowhere nothing around to lean your bike against its handy to have a kick stand depends where you're travelling to
data.author: Peter Tomlin

data.text: One kickstand? There are two on my Koga:an additional one in the front so the bike do not fall over when front paniers are added. I know, it is an extra weight, but I have cut a big chunk of my toothbrush stem, so it compensates 😀
data.author: Alain Seront

data.text: Using them for 44 years and never saw a reason not to have one. Exceptions: trail bike and DH bike, for obvious reasons.
data.author: Axel Knobbe

data.text: Oh my goodness...I have been wondering that for the longest time now...
data.author: Jena Workman

data.text: I dont use them - mostly because when the bike is heavy it falls over using a kickstand. Best to rest it on a tree.
data.author: Angela Mosley

data.text: Never used one, had on one of my bikes and just seemed too flimsy. Also hate random things attached to my bike. Seen many use kickstands though and there’s nothing wrong with one if it works for you👍🏽
data.author: Fazl Buchari

data.text: I use walking poles on my touring bike.
data.author: Peter Jeynes

data.text: I used one for a while but took it off. A bike with panniers on is easy to rest against a wall etc. Ultimately it's a matter of personal preference.
data.author: Mick Hine

data.text: No need- ugly and add weight. There are free inanimate objects around to lean against. Worst case, lay your bike down.
data.author: Christopher Ørr

data.text: Since this group is about touring bikes: A decent kick stand on a decent touring frame can hold up your bike even with a "six-pack" and when the ground isn't entirely flat. It's super useful, ESPECIALLY when loaded.
data.author: Thomas Arson

data.text: 80% of my bikes have kickstands.
data.author: Mick Allan

data.text: Save the weight. Take off the kick stand. Lean your bike against the wall.
data.author: Johnny Johnson

data.text: No stands on road bikes or trail bikes
data.author: George Homer

data.text: Home made from an old walking stick and cheap bracket 5yrs still works great total cost £1.hardly weighs anything
data.author: Michael Eldin

data.text: When touring i tried multiple stands including a two legged stand...they all broke under the weight of my panniers! No stand is strong enough to hold my bike up when touring at all!! 🤣😂
data.author: George Homer

data.text: I really like using my Clickstand. Supporting the loaded bike above its center of gravity gives a lot of stability.
data.author: Mark Thomas

data.text: love my click stand. What is the loaded weight of your bike if you don’t mind me asking?
data.author: George Hoffman

data.text: Even unloaded for the night…
data.author: Alan Edgar

data.text: No idea. It seems pretty heavy to me.
data.author: Mark Thomas

data.text: mine is currently sitting at 80 lbs loaded weight and it holds mine perfectly well. That’s 36 kg for my friends outside the US.
data.author: George Hoffman

data.text: , I’ll add, for the record, the key to CS success are the brake bands which secure the wheels. I use these pretty much always when stopped - and I would recommend them even for traditional kickstands and ‘leaning’ positions.
data.author: Alan Edgar

data.text: Twin leg works well on flat ground. Wife has one from the centre of rear wheel also works well.
data.author: Brad Yates
Brad Yates

data.text: I can't think of a reason I need it.
data.author: Nbs Guy

data.text: I find that they don’t work well in a loaded bike. I loop a strap to secure the front wheel and lean the bike. The same technique works along with a tent pole to keep the bike upright
data.author: Bryan Fennelly

data.text: I have a love/hate relationship w mine. It has two stands that form an upside- down "V," but raises the front wheel and of course adds weight, but my bike is a tank, so what's the difference? It is def convenient, but I often lean it.
data.author: MaryKay Simoni

data.text: The people who ride fancy gravel bikes in races do not have kick stands.
data.author: Bill Adkins

data.text: Nope it's more weight 🤣🤣🤣 I always lean bike against something or lay it down gently
data.author: Paul Ming Wiltshire

data.text: Nope
data.author: Christy Davidson James

data.text: Just extra weight IMO.
data.author: Kirk Stanford

data.text: Depends on the type of riding you do. Quick reasons not to have a kickstand: •On mountain bikes they could drop and then you could drop. •On road/race bikes they are added unneccesary weight. •On gravel, same as road and mtb. Commuting bikes may be a reasonable exception. I prop my bike with the pedal when I need to. If you like a kick stand and it's safe go for it. Do what you like!
data.author: Pendulumn JoAn Miner

data.text: If you're racing, you don't want the weight. If you're riding rough off-road stuff, you may want to avoid something that can accidentally deploy and cause an accident. Otherwise, it depends on whether the kickstand will simplify your life. I have one on the bike that I load up the heaviest.
data.author: Steve Williams

data.text: I love mine.
data.author: Ceecee Gowin

data.text: I would have liked to kickstand in the past but I've had so many bikes without them that I've gotten pretty good at figuring out how to lean my bike against various things in the world and never really need a kickstand anymore LOL
data.author: Clay Pardue

data.text: Once the $3,000 bike falls over because it wasn’t properly supported, you’ll start thinking about a kick stand. I’m not Armstrong so a few ounces isn’t going to make a diff. A bike with scuffed handle bar tape or a ripped leather seat just doesn’t look cool:)
data.author: Rodger Moran

data.text: I was on a group ride out of state. My bike had less than 1200 miles on it. When I bought it & asked about a kickstand, they acted like I was asking for turtleneck recommendations for the beach. I gently laid it drive side down b/c I didn't want to throw my rear view mirror out of whack. I ended up snapping my brand new hanger-- which ripped right through the spokes. It cost me $40 and a week to replace. I had to walk the last 5 miles of the ride. But hey, at least I wasn't one of those dorks with a kickstand.
data.author: Dave Grzelak

data.text: If you go to places where masses of people cycle, I think it's a good idea to have one. This is because there simply aren't enough walls and posts to lock every bike to and the general habit seems to be that people leave them freestanding (but locked) on their stands. I'm thinking about the Netherlands in particular. When for example I've wanted to eat at a particular place and still have sight of my bike and the panniers, that's when I've appreciated the uses of bikestands! Let's face it, your trip is absolutely over if someone steals your bike!
data.author: Sue Mosley

data.text: I take my bike into the washroom at the train station in the mall with me everywhere I don't trust anyone. I usually don't have any issues laying it on the ground especially the grass havnt done any bike packing quite yet though
data.author: Duell Kraft

data.text: That's not allowed anywhere in the Netherlands so that's where bikestands come in 😅
data.author: Laura Mora

data.text: Better than being a picnic table hog..lol
data.author: Ron Citynski

data.text: In open country, there is often nothing to prop up the bike against. I traveled several rail trails in Queensland Australia with a ClickStand, which I had to deploy numerous times an hour due to the need to open and close gates along the trail. Although I’m pretty quick with the process, my traveling companion wasn’t impressed 😉. I subsequently installed front and rear kick stands, and haven’t looked back.
data.author: Sam Reich

data.text: If you looked back, you might see your traveling companion, somewhere in the distance, impressed, or not.
data.author: Ignacio Duran

data.text: For my vintage and modern tandem, yes. For my mountain bikes, yes. For my vintage and modern road bikes, no. It's a personal preference. Start with a kickstand and remove it once you have a valid reason.
data.author: Mike Terry Hoggatt

data.text: Yes
data.author: Fredrick Sullivan

data.text: Nobody wants to carry an extra pound around all day.
data.author: Walt Conway

data.text: When the need arises, I complement the use of a kickstand by engaging the front brake with a length of Velcro tape and by using a jam jar lid to stop the foot of the stand sinking into soft ground.
data.author: Mike Shepperd

data.text: Hi folks, I am currently touring with full camp kit, in the UK and must admit being a roadie back home I have always thought that stands add too much weight, as Rodger above said a falling bike is bad news, think I will invest in one next trip as have had some near misses with bike wobble when parking up , safe travels folks and 🙂
data.author: David Brown

data.text: Not all bikes support a kickstand option. Many (not all) carbon frame bikes can’t use a kickstand.
data.author: Tony Carbone

data.text: On a "serious" bike, you don't want one because any time you leave the ground, you're risking that thing snapping down at an inopportune time and becoming a pogo stick. You say you don't leave the ground that often? Fine, keep the kickstand. It's got nothing to do with what most of these goobers think about why kickstands do and don't exist.
data.author: Scott Fulmer

data.text: nope, never need one (road bike)
data.author: Dave Stevens

data.text: My bicycle is never stationary so dont need one
data.author: Christopher Ørr

data.text: It depends on what type of serious cyclist you are referring to. Someone who carries gear and makes frequent stops absolutely needs one. The riders that you see in big groups on road bikes usually do not.
data.author: Eric Sepulveda

data.text: Old school kickstand is heavy and not that stable with a touring load, unless it an extra heavy double. A good alternative is a light tent pole or similar, cut to length so it wedges or hinges somewhere up high on the bike.
data.author: Ken Ward

data.text: Lots don’t. If riding a carbon frame, I get it. They are not designed for it and folks riding carbon think it adds too much weight. But many are overweight themselves and only ride at 13 mph avg. I ride steel. Some of my bikes already have a kickstand plate to bolt a stand onto. If you are careful and smart, you can mount a kickstand to a bike without a plate, but understand the limits. For recreational riders, not racing, I don’t understand not using one. They weigh little, and are so useful.
data.author: Ron Gurth

data.text: I removed the kickstand about the same time I took off training wheels, around age 4. Toured thousands of thru numerous countries, and commute to work for 20yrs and never needed one, and never seen a serious road bike or Mtn bike with a kick stand.
data.author: Brent Langlinais

data.text: You wouldn’t want to put one on a carbon bike, especially a performance road machine. There isn’t space and it would not be a good idea to add one to a chain stay .
data.author: Keith Goldstein

data.text: That would be like putting a towbar on a Ferrari...
data.author: Thomas Arson

data.text: Love my kickstand!
data.author: Patricia Roth
